stem: The hospital risk manager is auditing the EHR for a client who was placed in mechanical restraints. Based on the documentation in the Crisis Intervention Log and hospital policy, match each action with its legal safety status.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
20:00: Client (45y/o male) in alcohol withdrawal; exhibiting extreme violence towards staff. 
20:15: Soft 4-point restraints applied after de-escalation failure. 
20:45: Provider notified and arrived for face-to-face evaluation. 
21:30: Client currently sleeping; 4-point restraints remain in place.

tabs.title: Restraint Safety Standard
tabs.content:
1. Face-to-Face Evaluation must be within 60 minutes for adults. 
2. Renew order every 4 hours for behavioral reasons. 
3. Assessment and Release for ROM every 2 hours. 
4. Continuous monitoring or 15-minute intervals required for violent behavior.

rows.text: Performing a Face-to-Face evaluation within 1 hour of application
Renewing a behavioral restraint order every 8 hours
Securing the restraint ties to the side rails for easy release
Providing the client with ROM exercises and toileting every 2 hours
Writing a 'PRN' (As-needed) order for future restraint use

rationale.correct: Face-to-face evaluation within 1 hour is a Joint Commission and CMS standard (r1). Behavioral orders must be renewed every 4 hours, not 8 (r2). Tying to side rails is dangerous and non-compliant (r3). 2-hour releases for ROM/toileting is standard care (r4). PRN orders for restraints are NEVER legal (r5).
clinicalPearls: Restraints are for safety only, never as punishment or for convenience.
A quick-release knot tied to the bed frame is the only acceptable method.
The nurse must document that all less-restrictive measures were tried and failed first.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that 'Medical/Surgical' restraint and 'Behavioral' restraint follow the same renewal rules.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Behavioral = 4 hours. Medical = 24 hours. Always check why the patient is in restraints (violence vs. pulling at a tube).
